title: Autonomous Boat Structural Upgrade - Lightweight Modular Aluminium Frame
overview: The goal of this project was to replace an old, impractical aluminum tube frame that was difficult to assemble with a new modular structure based on V-slot aluminum profiles.

The primary objectives were to increase structural stiffness and significantly simplify assembly and disassembly, as the boat was designed for air transport as oversized luggage to international competitions (USA, Norway).
The new frame architecture also enabled easier integration of additional onboard equipment by leveraging widely used V-slot mounting standards.
highlights: I designed a new structural frame based on V-slot aluminum profiles, with dedicated mounting points for key subsystems such as cameras, the electronics enclosure, and the LiDAR sensor.
The number of frame-to-float mounting points was increased from four to six in order to improve overall structural stiffness and load distribution.
I selected and ordered all profiles and connectors, cut the aluminum profiles to length, and assembled the complete frame.
New frame-to-float mounting brackets were designed, as the previous ones were dedicated to aluminum tubes and incompatible with V-slot profiles.
The redesigned mounting brackets were optimized to be lighter and more functional than the previous generation.

All mounting brackets were manufactured using 3D printing from ASA filament, chosen for its resistance to high temperatures and harsh environmental conditions encountered during competitions in Florida.
results: The new frame is extremely quick to assemble and disassemble; for car transport, removing six bolts is sufficient to separate the boat into three compact parts (two floats and the electronics frame).
Following the upgrade, the frame has remained in continuous use and is considered a long-term solution, with no planned redesign in the foreseeable future.
